profileText: A Representative from Vermont; born in Bennington, Vt., July 20, 1795; attended the common schools; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1819 and commenced practice in Bennington; member of the State house of representatives in 1827; clerk of Benton County in 1828 and 1829; State's attorney 1828-1831; elected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-second Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Jonathan Hunt; reelected as an Anti-Jacksonian to the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Congresses and elected as a Whig to the Twenty-fifth through Twenty-seventh Congresses and served from January 1, 1833, to March 3, 1843; chairman, Committee on Revolutionary Claims (Twenty-seventh Congress); was not a candidate for renomination in 1842; State bank commissioner 1843-1846; judge of the State supreme court 1846-1850; Second Comptroller of the Treasury from November 27, 1850, to September 10, 1851; United States land commissioner for California 1851-1854; returned to Vermont; Governor of Vermont 1858-1860; member of the peace convention of 1861 held in Washington, D.C., in an effort to devise means to prevent the impending war; died in Springfield, Mass., December 18, 1885; interment in Bennington Center Cemetery, Bennington, Vt.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by death of Jonathan Hunt, and took his seat January 21, 1833.

researchRecord.description: Correspondence of Hiland Hall, chiefly relating to his political career and to his historical research.$bIncludes letters to Trenor W. Park and his wife, Laura (Hall) Park, daughter of Hiland Hall, James H. Trumbull, Isaac Jennings, Benson J. Lossing, and Justin S. Morrill. Letters to Hall include one from Carlos Coolidge. Early letters to Hall relate to his time as member of Congress, while later letters concern his historical work. Correspondents include Zadock Thompson, Jared Sparks, Larkin G. Mead, Jr., Ryland Fletcher, Henry B. Dawson, Erastus Fairbanks, Silas H. Jenison, Lorenzo Fassett, and Abby Maria Hemenway. Subjects include the Battle of Bennington, Peleg Sutherland, and the publication of Abby Hemenway's Vermont Historical Gazetteer. Biographical and personal materials include a broadside from the Congressional election of 1832 and a tally of votes from the 1834 election as well as an early engraving of Hall. There is also a sketch of the Catamount Tavern by Hall's granddaughter and notes on the life of Remember Baker. Also includes promissory note (1786) to Hiland Hall, presumably Hall's great-grandfather. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Hall-Cushman family papers, 1786-ca. 1930, 52 file folders.
researchRecord.description: The records are chiefly correspondence of Hiland Hall and his family and Civil War and business records of Henry T. Cushman. The Hall family correspondence is mostly letters to Hiland Hall from his wife, Dolly, two sons (Henry D. Hall and Nathaniel B. Hall), and Martha B. Hall, wife of Nathaniel B. Hall. There are two folders of letters (1838-1841) by Hiland Hall, in Washington, D.C., mostly to his wife Dolly and son Henry, when he was serving in the U.S. House of Representatives. Also included is family correspondence regarding the death and estate of Hiland Hall.
